PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: WTI crude futures rose around 6% to above USD 57/bbl
content:
AUSTRALIA

Boral (BLD AT) - Co. signs property agreement with Mirvac (MGR AT) and affirms FY19 guidance for EBITDA from property earnings at around AUD 30mln. (Newswires)

Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA AT) - Co. is reportedly mulling the future for its CommSec Advisory and is expected to invite multiple firms to tender for the business. (Newswires)

Lynas (LYC AT) - Co. announces MOU with Blue Line Corp for a JV to develop rare earths separation capacity in US. (Newswires)

South32 (S32 AT) - Co. received bids from Mercuria Consortium and Seriti for its coal assets. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT) - Co. reportedly succumbed to APRA warnings and reinstated a key lending restriction which it had previously inexplicably dropped. (AFR)

Energy - WTI crude futures rallied around 6% to above USD 57.00/bbl. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. signed exclusive deal with Alphabet’s Waymo for driverless services, while it was also reported that Renault (RNO FP) agreed to support Nissan's management reform plan. (Newswire/Nikkei)

Rakuten (4755 JT) - Co. and Yamato Transport are among the companies that are to partner with the government to test unmanned delivery robots on public roads. (Nikkei)

Other News - BoJ Governor Kuroda reiterated to patiently continue with current powerful monetary easing and stated it is possible for forward guidance to be pushed back beyond Spring 2020. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Geopolitics - North Korean leader Kim said he will maintain patience in efforts to resolve the Korean Peninsula issue, while it was also reported that Kim and Chinese President Xi agreed their nations need to work together in the face of a changing international environment. (Yonhap/KCNA)

Other News - BoK said the domestic economy and financial markets will remain resilient even under the worst case scenario. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US and China negotiating teams could meet as soon as Tuesday. (SCMP)

A senior administration official said the White House is not looking for a big breakthrough deal when Trump meets with Xi Jinping at the G-20 in Japan, according to Politico's Morning Money. (Politico)

China Global Times Editor made retaliatory comments to US Senator Rubio in which he alleged that Rubio keeps attaching labels to China as well as poisoning the perception of Chinese and American society towards each other. (Twitter)

China-EU investment access talks went better than expected and were “deeper than normal”, while the parties agreed to hold further meetings each month from July to speed up the process, according to diplomatic sources. Furthermore, reports also noted that China signed significant deals with Britain as it shores up alliances during the trade dispute with US. (Newswires/SCMP)

 

UK/EU

BoE kept monetary policy setting unchanged as expected in which it voted unanimously (9-0) to hold rates at 0.75%, as well as maintain the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln and stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln.

MPC maintained guidance that rates will be raised at a gradual pace and to a limited extent, while it noted that near-term data has been broadly in-line with projections made in the May report and downside risks to growth have increased in which it cited global trade tensions and the increasing risk of a no-deal Brexit. MPC also reiterated guidance that the monetary policy response to Brexit will not be automatic and could be in either direction, while it added that after 0.5% growth seen in Q1, Q2 GDP is expected to be flat (Prev. view of 0.2%) and that CPI is likely to slip below the 2% target this year amid declines in energy prices. (Newswires)

Boris Johnson maintained the lead after rounds 4 and 5 of the Conservative leadership ballot in which Javid and then Gove were eliminated. The latest results showed Boris Johnson with 160 votes, Jeremy Hunt at 77 votes and Michael Gove at 75 votes which sets up a runoff between Johnson and Hunt. (Newswires)

  • UK Retail Sales (May) M/M -0.5% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Rev. -0.1%). (Newswires)
  • UK Retail Sales (May) Y/Y 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 5.2%, Rev. 5.1%)
  • EU Consumer Confidence Flash (Jun) -7.2 vs. Exp. -6.5 (Prev. -6.5)

 

COMMODITIES

Saudi June output will reportedly be around May levels of 9.67mln BPD which is below its 10.3mln BPD target, while reports also noted that Russia still has not agreed to extend cuts until year-end according to sources. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump tweeted that “Iran made a very big mistake!" and answered "you'll soon find out" when asked if the US will strike Iran. However, President Trump later added that he does not feel like his administration is pushing him toward conflict and in some cases it’s the opposite, while he suggested the drone shooter could have been someone who was "loose and stupid". (Newswires/Twitter)

US Military official said the US surveillance mission near the Strait of Hormuz was in international airspace and there were reports that US naval assets have been dispatched to the drone debris field in international waters. Elsewhere, House Speaker Pelosi said the US does not want to go to war with Iran but the situation is dangerous and geopolitical consultancy Stratfor commented that the shooting down of the US drone rapidly raises the prospect of a military confrontation between US and Iran. (Newswires)

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif alleged that the US wages economic terrorism on Iran and stated we don't seek war, but will zealously defend our skies, land and waters. Furthermore, Iran's Revolutionary Guard Top Commander Salami said the downing of the US drone sent a clear message to Washington and that Tehran will react strongly against any acts of aggression, while he added that borders are the nation's red line and that Tehran is not looking for war with any nation but is ready to defend itself.

Iranian-backed Houthi's launched large-scale drone attacks on UAVs and military targets at Saudi's Jizan Airport, although Saudi air defences intercepted a Houthi drone strike in Jizan according to a Saudi-led coalition spokesperson. In other news, Saudi Arabia warned there will be a very strong reaction if the Strait of Hormuz is ever closed by Iran. (Newswires/ELINT News)

US State Department official said sanctions against Turkey remain a viable option and that the US along with other NATO partners remain persistent in telling Turkey there are alternatives to the S-400. However, there were also comments from Turkish President Erdogan who reiterated that the purchase of the S-400 missile system is a "done deal" and that Ankara will reciprocate if Washington imposes sanctions. (Newswires)

Russian President Putin said he is ready for dialogue with US President Trump and doesn't think relations will be all easy. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump said Fed chair Powell will eventually "do what is right", while he also commented that US and Canada have come a long way on the USMCA agreement and hopes for bipartisan support. (Newswires)

US Philly Fed Business Index (Jun) 0.3 vs. Exp. 11.0 (Prev. 16.6). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Oracle (ORCL) jumped higher after reporting earnings that beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom lines. Newmont Goldcorp (NEM) moved higher as the Gold rally. Petro names, including ExxonMobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) moved higher as oil prices rallied on geopolitical tensions. On which note, airlines, including Delta Airlines (DAL) and American Airlines (AAL) were also under pressure as fuel prices rose. However, the outlook for vacations consumption may also have weighed, after Carnival Corp (CCL) sunk on poor earnings guidance dragging Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings (NCLH) and Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL) with it. Tesla (TSLA) was under pressure after Goldman reduced its PT for the electric automaker. Darden Restaurants (DRI) pared the worst of losses sustained pre-market, after the co missed revenue expectations and cut guidance. Hershey (HSY) was under pressure after being downgraded to hold from neutral at Piper Jaffray. Dell Technologies (DELL) moved higher after being initiated with a buy at Deutsche Bank. Perrigo (PRGO) came under some late session selling on reports that interest for its RX unit had faded. S&P 500 1% at 2954, NASDAQ-100 0.9% at 7738, Dow Jones 0.9% at 26754.

The T-plex continued to trade higher on Thursday, sending yields even lower, in the wake of a now non-patient Fed with an eye for rate cuts. The Fed-sensitive front end of the curve saw the most bidding seeing the 2-year yield drop c. 3bps at settlement. The curve itself saw some modest flattening where the 2s/10s contracted by c. 2bps. The US also sold USD 15bln in 5-year TIPS on Thursday at a high yield of 0.152%, with a chunky indirects takedown (75.73%), a B/C of 2.55x, and tailing by 0.2bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 6+ ticks higher at 128-02.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 20th June 2019: SPX new ATHs; US to decide on Iran retaliation
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Trump says Iran made “big mistake” in drone attack; Markets digest dovish Fed; dismal Philly Fed Index; BoE & BoJ leaves rates unchanged, whilst Norges hikes.
  • COMING UP: Aussie Manufacturing, Services & Comp June PMI; Japan May CPI, Manufacturing PMI; EZ Flash PMI; Canada Retail Sales; US Markit Manufacturing, Services & Comp Flash PMI, Baker Hughes; Fed’s Mester, Fed’s Daly.

 

* IRAN: The tensions in the Persian Gulf escalated on Thursday following the Iran's Revolutionary Guard shooting down a US drone. Debate remains over whether the drone was flying in Iranian airspace or not, where IRGC Commander Salami said the downing of the drone sent a clear message to Washington that Tehran will react strongly against any acts of aggression in its borders. However, the US state that the drone was flying in international airspace. US President Trump since said that Iran had made a very big mistake, and later convened with military generals, as well as holding a briefing with congressional leaders. Later, when asked if the US will strike Iran, US President Trump said "you'll soon find out" although in the same interview he opted to dial back the rhetoric somewhat, saying he does not feel like his administration is pushing him toward conflict and in some cases it’s just the opposite, whilst suggesting that the drone shooter could have been someone who was “loose and stupid”.

* FOMC – SIZE OF RATE CUT IS NOW THE QUESTION: With markets pricing a July rate cut with over 100% certainty, the question is now shifting towards whether the Fed will trim rates by 25bps, or by 50bps. Fed chair Powell on Wednesday cited research which suggested it might be better to cut by a larger margin in order to prevent any prolonged weakness, though stopped short of committing to any size, saying the FOMC have not discussed the increment. Desks have suggested that it could put the Fed in an awkward position: if markets are expecting a cut of 50bps, a cut of 25bps may disappoint by 25bps.

* US PHILLY FED INDEX: The US Philly Fed Business Index came in at 0.3 for the month of June, well below the consensus for 11.0 and May print of 16.6. Pantheon Macroeconomics note they are not surprised by the Philly Fed index for May plunging to 0.3 (prev. 16.6). They cite the plunge in the Empire State index as being an indication that the Philly Fed consensus was unrealistic given that both surveys were taken during the Mexico tariff episode. The consultancy highlights the index’s volatility due to trade developments, but the more stable new orders and employment components fell by a more modest 2.7 and 2.8 points respectively.

* BOE REVIEW: Despite some minor outside bets for hawkish dissent on the MPC, policymakers opted once again to stand pat on rates at 0.75% via a unanimous vote. This week’s meeting took place against a backdrop of MPC members hammering home to markets that rate rises will be coming at a faster pace than currently priced in the market (Aug 2020 is currently showing 11bps of tightening), however, these hawkish impulses didn’t see any particular airing this week other than the statement retaining its guidance that “rates will be raised at a gradual pace and to a limited extent”. In fact, the tone of the statement held a relatively cautious slant with the MPC noting that “downside risks to growth have increased”; citing global trade tensions and the increasing risk of a no deal Brexit. This sentiment was also reflected in the Bank’s decision to cut their Q2 GDP forecast to flat from a prior view of +0.2%. On the Brexit front, policymakers opted to maintain guidance that “the monetary policy response to Brexit, whatever form it takes, will not be automatic and could be in either direction”, in what was otherwise a relatively tame release. Overall, ING concludes “we wouldn’t totally rule out a rate hike from the Bank of England later this year if wage growth continues to perform solidly and the immediate threat from Brexit recedes”. However, the Dutch Bank ultimately concedes that “it is unlikely the Bank will hike rates this year”.

* BOJ REVIEW: The BOJ kept all policy settings unchanged; as major global  central banks pivot dovish, some were expecting the BOJ to provide some clear signals that it could follow the dovish trend, particularly in wake of Governor Kuroda’s recent comments where he reiterated that the BOJ had scope to ease policy further to achieve its inflation goals. “Strong domestic fundamentals continue to offset the negative shocks from uncertainties overseas,” Societe Generale said, “economic data continues to show strength in the domestic economy,” and under such circumstances, the bank says the BOJ is likely to maintain the view that it could continue to wait for further data and developments. SocGen’s central scenario is that the BOJ will keep rates unchanged until 2021, after the Tokyo Olympic games: “That said, if risks to achieving the 2% inflation target strengthen, then BOJ policy board members could give more indications that it would be ready to act if needed, following the recent trend of global central bankers,” SocGen argues.

* ITALY: In what was familiar rhetoric, Italian PM Conte reiterated criticisms of EU fiscal rules; saying that rules should focus on growth, whilst also criticising partners for unfair tax advantages and for running excessive surpluses (Netherlands and Germany).

* UK: There are now suggestions that Conservative Leadership candidate frontrunner Boris Johnson would mull early elections, in the event he wins the keys to Downing Street; the Johnson team feels that a charismatic leader could win an outright majority vs Labour. Boris Johnson subsequently maintained his lead in latest conservative leadership ballot rounds, with Michael Gove and Sajid Javid eliminated, leaving Jeremy Hunt as the only remaining challenger to the favourite.

* ECB: Largely a reiteration of ECB President Draghi comments on Tuesday: ECB's de Guindos (Neutral) said the Bank is ready to act if the deterioration continues, whilst, in the same vein, ECB's Knot suggested the bank is actively thinking about emergency plans in the event that growth does not pick up.

* NORGES BANK REVIEW: The Norges Bank unanimously delivered on the 25bps June hike, with the Key Rate now at 1.25%, as expected.” Governor Olsen highlighted that the “assessment of the outlook and balance of risks suggests that the policy rate will most likely be increased further in the course of 2019”, as Governor Olsen noted that the rate path suggests a September hike followed by an additional hike before Summer 2020. In-fitting with some of the house calls, the rate path was left unchanged from the March release. Overall, the statement painted an upbeat picture of the economy and outlook; “Underlying inflation is a little higher than the inflation target”, “Growth in the Norwegian economy is solid, and capacity utilisation is estimated to be somewhat above a normal level. The NB did however acknowledge that a deepening in trade tensions and softer oil prices could weigh on the domestic economy. All-in-all a hawkish hike, which was reflected by the markets as EUR/NOK slid from around 9.7240 to 6.6700.

* RBA: Governor Lowe argued that there was a “fair degree” of spare capacity in the labour market, while recent data, including the labour market report and GDP data did not suggest that any inroads were being made in terms of eroding this spare capacity; accordingly, Lowe said that it was “not unreasonable” to expect further easing from the central bank. Some had argued that the recent meeting minutes have opened up the door to potential QE in the future. However, some analysts noted that Lowe reiterated that monetary, fiscal and micro policy were all “options” (e said the word three times in the speech); given that the RBA’s Bulletin did not have any guidance on QE “options” (the Bulletin did not contain any article laying the foundation to QE), some have suggested that it was a deliberate attempt by the governor to play down potential QE. Others have noted that in 2007-2011, the central bank made use of open market operations (FX forwards and repos) to ease conditions, making it likely it could explore this tool again.

* WTI futures (Q9) settle USD 3.10 higher at USD 57.07/bbl; Brent futures (Q9) settle USD 2.63 higher at USD 64.45/BBL: A perfect storm of geopolitical risk and a Fed induced appetite for risk (and, as a result, the weaker USD) saw the crude complex surge on Thursday. Prices were initially on the front foot as market participants digested the FOMC meeting, which lead to rising expectations of near-term US interest rate cuts, seeing US equities reach new all time highs. On top of this, the geopolitical risk premium became more pronounced after a US drone was shot down by Iran, helping crude markets rally further on supply concerns out of the oil-rich region. It is worth noting that although WTI did outperform its European counterpart, part of this would be a factor of the July WTI future contract expiring. Analysts at Citigroup on the near-term crude outlook said, “At least for the moment, we see no immediate bearish fundamental to counterbalance this bullish combination.”

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 6+ TICKS HIGHER AT 128-02: The T-plex continued to trade higher on Thursday, sending yields even lower, in the wake of a now non-patient Fed with an eye for rate cuts. The Fed-sensitive front end of the curve saw the most bidding seeing the 2-year yield drop c. 3bps at settlement. The curve itself saw some modest flattening where the 2s/10s contracted by c. 2bps. The US also sold USD 15bln in 5-year TIPS on Thursday at a high yield of 0.152%, with a chunky indirects takedown (75.73%), a B/C of 2.55x, and tailing by 0.2bps.

* S&P 500 1% at 2954, NASDAQ-100 0.9% at 7738, Dow Jones 0.9% at 26754, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.7%, Consumer Staples 0.8%, Energy 2.2%, Financials  0.5%, Health Care 0.4%, Industrials 1.6%, Information Technology 1.4%, Materials 1.2%, Telecommunication Services 0.6%, Utilities 0.5%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Oracle (ORCL) jumped higher after reporting earnings that beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom lines. Newmont Goldcorp (NEM) moved higher as the Gold rally. Petro names, including ExxonMobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) moved higher as oil prices rallied on geopolitical tensions. On which note, airlines, including Delta Airlines (DAL) and American Airlines (AAL) were also under pressure as fuel prices rose. However, the outlook for vacations consumption may also have weighed, after Carnival Corp (CCL) sunk on poor earnings guidance dragging Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings (NCLH) and Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL) with it. Tesla (TSLA) was under pressure after Goldman reduced its PT for the electric automaker. Darden Restaurants (DRI) pared the worst of losses sustained pre-market, after the co missed revenue expectations and cut guidance. Hershey (HSY) was under pressure after being downgraded to hold from neutral at Piper Jaffray. Dell Technologies (DELL) moved higher after being initiated with a buy at Deutsche Bank. Perrigo (PRGO) came under some late session selling on reports that interest for its RX unit had faded.

* FX WRAP: USD continued its decline as the market continued to digest yesterday’s dovish FOMC, and was the worst G10 performer, with markets now seemingly split over whether the next Fed move will be a 50bps or 25bps rate cut, rather than split over whether or not there will even be a rate cut. On the other side coin, EUR was strong, moving back towards 1.1300 while Gold (XAU) has continued its rally, edging closer to USD 1400. Across the channel, the BoE maintained its hiking bias, but the minutes came across dovish, especially when compared with recent comments from Saunders, Haldane and Carney. As such GBP came off somewhat, EURGBP moving as high as 0.8920 on the day, before paring gains to consolidate around 0.8880. JPY was largely unaffected by the BoJ who opted to stand pat, and traded much more as a function of the weakening dollar and global risk appetite; USDJPY broke out of the bottom of the June range, where losses had previously been capped at 107.80 (on USD weakness), before a further bout of downside triggered by a certain Trump tweet (“Iran has made a very big mistake”) saw the pair move as low as 107.25. Likewise, CHF was also significantly stronger, with dovish ECB talk, Italian fiscal jitters and disappointing Eurozone survey news doing little to help. Indeed, EURCHF fell below 1.1100, a level that some analysts have suggested may be a line in the sand for the SNB. NOK was a G10 outperformer, as the Norges Bank went further than delivering the expected 25 bps hike, pencilling in 2 more hikes, likely in this September and before Summer 2020. As such, EURNOK broke back below 9.7000 and continues to make headway toward 9.6500. Elsewhere on the CB policy front; dovish comments from RBA’s Lowe, in which he hinted at the need for further rate cuts, resulted in temporary downside for the AUD, however losses were capped, as antipodeans continued to rally on the dollar’s demise and improved optimism for a US/China trade deal. AUDUSD moved back above 0.69 while NZDUSD advanced toward 0.66 (from lows of 0.6490 earlier in the week). EMFX rallied as the dollar came off. ZAR was relatively unmoved during a SOTU from SA President Ramaphosa and was relatively subdued after a rather downbeat ratings outlook from Fitch, with USDZAR consolidating around 14.3000. TRY fared slightly better in wake of a rise in Turkish consumer confidence and despite more interjections from President Erdogan on the Russian S-400 missile front (done deal and order to arrive early next month), which caused a brief bout of downside. Note also, he repeated that benchmark rates should be lower in similar vein to his US peer, but USDTRY remains capped ahead of 5.8000, albeit off lows under 5.7300.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: contrasting Central Bank impulses and conflicting geopolitical assertions
content:
GBP/NOK/JPY/AUD/USD

All under the influence of, if not totally transfixed on CB policy or guidance as the BoE maintained a tightening bias, but added some provisos that countered recent more hawkish remarks from certain MPC members. Conversely, the Norges Bank stuck to its script when delivering another 25 bp hike and went several steps further by pencilling in 2 more ¼ point tightening moves, like in September this year and before Summer 2020. The Bank added that is rate path signals a slightly faster pace of normalisation than in March based on a robust domestic economy vs downside risks elsewhere and softer oil prices. Elsewhere, the BoJ maintained that powerful stimulus is needed to meet the inflation target and if that objective is threatened then more measure will be implemented, while RBA’s Lowe reaffirmed the case for more easing. Earlier, the Fed removed patience from its statement and dots within the SEP to pave the way for a potential or probable cut at the July FOMC. Moreover, with 7 members now plotting looser policy in H2 this year and those remaining unchanged to keep the 2019 consensus flat said to be more open to easing, according to Chair Powell, the size of a move could be bigger than the standard 25 bp. Hence, the Buck has been the net loser with Cable up to circa 1.2725 at one stage and only crimped by soft UK retail sales and the aforementioned not as hawkish BoE minutes and vote than some anticipated. Usd/Nok and Eur/Nok hit lows sub-8.5400 and 9.6600 respectively before consolidating, while the Yen finally breached 108.00 and support just under the big figure on its way down to 107.50, as the Aussie managed to stay mostly above 0.6900 in large part due to the Greenback’s demise. Indeed, the DXY is teetering just above 96.500 and post-NFP lows with additional pressure from a bleak Philly Fed survey and increasingly strained US-Iran relations following a drone said to have been downed by the IRGC, which Tehran contends was violating boundaries, but Washington insists was in international airspace.

CAD/NZD/CHF/EUR

Aside from the Usd weakness noted above, the Loonie derived some momentum from spiking crude prices to offset a fall in Canadian ADP and extended post-CPI gains to circa 1.3150 at best, while the Kiwi almost touched 0.6600 on the back of encouraging NZ GDP overnight and Franc got close to 0.9800 after a wider than previous Swiss trade surplus with watch exports rebounding strongly. Note, Eur/Chf has retreated further from 1.1200+ recently to under 1.1100, as the single currency failed to sustain gains above 1.1300 vs the Dollar amidst more dovish ECB talk, Italian fiscal jitters and disappointing Eurozone survey news.

EM 

The Rand is treading cautiously ahead of the SOTU from SA President Ramaphosa (from around 18.00BST) and after a rather downbeat ratings outlook from Fitch, with Usd/Zar back above 14.3000 vs sub-14.2000 earlier in the session, but the Lira fares slightly better in wake of a rise in Turkish consumer confidence and despite more interjections from President Erdogan on the Russian S-400 missile front (done deal and order to arrive early next month). Note also, he repeated that benchmark rates should be lower in similar vein to his US peer, but Usd/Try remains capped ahead of 5.8000, albeit some way off lows under 5.7300.

DOW

  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) was initiated with a Hold and price target of USD 205 at Deutsche Bank, analysts citing potential for 2019 iPhone cycle "lull" ahead of 5G iPhones in 2020. Elsewhere, it has not decided yet whether or not to shift production from China, Apple is still examining feasibility, according to WSJ.
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is reportedly in discussions with other airlines showing an interest in its 737 MAX. This follows a letter of intent for 200 planes from IAG (ICAGY) at the Paris Airshow on Tuesday.
  • Intel (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors), Microsoft (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software), Dell Technologies (DELL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) and HP (HPQ) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) are collaborating in opposition to the Trump Administration’s proposed tariffs of a further USD 300bln in Chinese goods, which could include laptops and tablets.
  • United Technologies (UTX) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence), Raytheon (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) - Aerospace executives reportedly see potential benefits from the proposed merger of equals between Raytheon and United Technologies. These could include better margins for suppliers and possibly the chance to bid on any divisions being divested as the merging defence co.s seek regulatory approval.
  • UnitedHealth Group (UNH) (Health Care/Managed Health Care) has won anti-trust approval for its plans to buy DaVita's primary & urgent care unit in a deal worth USD 4.3bln, the FTC announced on Wednesday.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet’s (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) YouTube and Major League Baseball released details of the first three matchups included in their agreement to stream 13 live games every week on the YouTube platform.
  • Amgen (AMGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) will team up with the University of Washington's Institute for Protein Design (IPD) to create custom-designed proteins, in a collaboration that will span multiple projects.
  • Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) plans to create its global cryptocurrency, Libra, will come under US Senate Banking Committee scrutiny on July 16.
  • Netflix’s (NFLX) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) new movie, Murder Mystery, was viewed by over 30.9mln people in the first three days, its biggest move launch ever.
  • Of note for gaming names, including EA (EA), TakeTwo (TTWO) and Activision Blizzard (ATVI); in preparation for the next generation of games consoles, that will launch in 2020, video games sales slowed in May, reported Business Insider citing NPD data. May video game sales were down 13% Y/Y in May.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) had its price target lowered to USD 158 from USD 200 at Goldman Sachs. Analysts noted that shares have recently been bouncing back amid optimism about near-term deliveries. However, while they think Q2 should be fine with the company likely to achieve volumes near consensus forecasts, analysts think volume estimates for the second half of the year and beyond look high considering the company has “fewer levers left to pull” given that Tesla has already released lower priced Model 3 variants, introduced leasing and right-hand drive orders have started. Moreover, another step-down in the US federal tax credit for Tesla vehicles is coming on July 1st.
  • T-Mobile US (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) is preparing an alternative plan if a deal to sell wireless assets to Dish Network (DISH) fails to materialise.

S&P 500

  • Carnival Corp (CCL) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) (USD) report Q1 EPS 0.66 (exp. 0.61), revenue 4.84bln (exp. 4.53bln), cuts FY adj. EPS 4.25-4.35 (prev. 4.35-4.55), weighing on the wider sector in the pre-market.
  • Darden Resaurants (DRI) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) (USD) reports Q1 adj. EPS 1.76 (exp. 1.73), revenue 2.23bln (exp. 2.24bln), sees FY20 diluted EPS 6.30-6.45 (exp. 6.46).
  • Delta Airlines (DAL) (Industrials/Airlines) said it was not expecting any flight cancellations as a result of a technical glitch that had compromised booking, check-in and boarding services.
  • Discovery (DISCA) (Communication Services/Broadcasting) has struck a multi-year deal with FuboTV, that will bring 13 of the cable-programmer's networks to Fubo's live-TV streaming service in coming weeks.
  • Marathon Petroleum Corp (MRO) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) has received a request from three US House of Representatives Democrats on Wednesday, who have asked the energy co. to disclose any communications between itself and the White House regarding the Trump administration's recent proposal to hold fuel efficiency standards at 2020 levels through to 2026, amid concerns the co. was involved in the controversial proposal’s development.
  • Oracle (ORCL) (Information Technology/Application Software) (USD) reports Q4 19 adj. EPS 1.16 (exp. 1.08), Revenue 11.1bln (exp. 10.94bln); total cloud services and license support plus cloud license and on-premise license revenue were up 3% at 9.3bln.
  • United Pacific Corp’s (UNP) (Industrials/Railroads) CEO said further tariffs on Chinese imports could badly hurt its railroad business and the US economy more broadly but did say he felt President Trump is listening to the concerns of businesses.

OTHER

  • Aecom (ACM) (Industrials/Construction & Engineering) - Starboard Value LP, who owns approximately 4.0% of the outstanding common stock, delivered letter to ACM’s CEO and board saying its belief that Aecom’s assets are deeply undervalued, pressing the co. for a strategic review.
  • Deutsche Bank (DB) (Financials/Diversified Banks) is being probed by Federal authorities over whether or not the bank complied with laws designed to prevent money laundering.
  • GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has offered concessions to the EU, as it looks to address antitrust concerns the co.’s proposed joint venture with Pfizer's (PFE) consumer health business.
  • PG&E (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) provided an update on its accelerated and enhanced safety inspections and repairs conducted in high-fire threat areas over the past six months, reporting that the co. had completed visual inspections of approximately 99% of its distribution infrastructure and visual or aerial inspections of approximately 98% of its transmission infrastructure.
  • Renault (RNSDF, RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers), CEO Bollore said the automaker is not planning to reduce its stake in alliance partner Nissan (NSANY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) in order to secure a deal with Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers), following the collapse of recent merger talks. Elsewhere, the automakers have partnered with Waymo, an Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) subsidiary, to explore aspects of driverless mobility services for both passengers and deliveries in France and Japan.

subject: UBS still sees USD to outperform
content:
• Says the broad rule of thumbis for the USD to outperform; due to either US yields higher (the rate channel story) or US outperformance of rest-of-world (the capital flow story). 
  • "Longer-term (over a month) it comes back to an argument of capital flows, these remain heavily skewed towards the US, and that is something yesterday's FOMC signal isn't likely to change," UBS says, "for outward investment to pick-up and exceed inward investment, a significant turn of the growth outlook is needed (and that's asking a lot from the G20)." 
  • "The relative ranking for the US still outperforms in the G10 both on GDP terms and Cost-of-Capital (carry). FX at its purest expression reflects capital flow. This flow argument is directionally aligned with the call for a stronger USD through 2019," adding that clearly yesterday's meeting challenges the US yields higher argument, so short-run USD weakness wouldn't surprise anyone.

subject: BoE Agents Summary of Business Conditions Q2 2019
content:
• Retail sales growth remained subdued
  • Brexit uncertainty weighed on demand for business services
  • Manufacturing output growth was moderate
  • Investment intentions have weakened
  • Employment intentions eased and growth in labour costs steadied

subject: BoE June Minutes Summary: MPC votes 9-0 in favour of maintaining rates at 0.75% - as expected
content:
• Vote split on the base rate: MPC votes 9-0 to stand pat on rates at 0.75%
  • Vote split on corporate bonds: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln
  • Vote split on APF: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln
  • Overall: MPC notes that near-term data has been broadly in-line with projections made in the May report, however, downside risks to growth have increased; cites global trade tensions and increasing risk of a no deal Brexit
  • Rates: Maintains guidance that rates will be raised at a gradual pace and to a limited extent
  • Brexit: Maintains guidance that the monetary policy response to Brexit, whatever form it takes, will not be automatic and could be in either direction
  • Growth: After 0.5% growth seen in Q1, Q2 GDP is expected to be flat (Prev. view of 0.2%); in part reflects an unwinding of stockpiling seen in Q1
  • Inflation: CPI is likely to slip below the 2% target this year amid declines in energy prices
  • Investment: Weak business investment has persisted
  • Labour/wages: Market remains tight and broadly in line with projections made in the May report
  • APF: MPC has agreed to reinvest GBP 3.8bln of cash flows associated with the redemption of the July 2019 Gilt held by the APF
reaction_details:
In an immediate reaction to the release (i.e. increased downside risk, Brexit uncertainty, weak business investment persisting):

  • GBP/USD fell 25 pips from 1.2715 to 1.2690
  • Gilts Sept'19 rose 33 ticks from 130.35 to 130.68
  • Short-sterling strip back months +3-4 ticks from pre-BoE levels

  • European equities higher across the board as investors cheer the Fed
  • DXY lower, NOK bolstered by hawkish Norges hike
  • Looking ahead, highlights include BoE rate decision US weekly jobs, Philly Fed, BoE’s Carney

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive as the region digested the dovish FOMC. ASX 200 (+0.6%) was led higher by gold names after the precious metal surged to its highest since 2013 but with upside in the broader market capped by weakness in other miners including Rio Tinto after it lowered its iron ore production outlook and with Caltex heavily pressured on disappointing guidance. Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) was also supported in the aftermath of the FOMC although a firmer currency and unsurprising BoJ announcement limited the advances, while Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.4%) outperformed on optimism ahead of the US-China trade talks and as financials surged after continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they tracked the upside in T-notes amid a decline in global yields with the US 10yr yield below 2.00% for the first time since November 2016 and with the 30yr yield also at similar multi-year lows.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos. PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8805 (Prev. 6.8893)

Early talks suggest G20 members' frustration regarding US-China trade spat and that there is mounting pressure on the world's two largest economies to ease trade tensions. (FT)

US President Trump and Chinese President Xi are expected to meet over dinner on June 29th in Japan. President Trump says he will also be meeting with Russian President Putin at the G20. (Newswires)

USTR Lighthizer said will meet with China VP Liu He this week and again before the Trump-Xi meeting at G20. (Newswires)

New Zealand GDP (Q1) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%), Y/Y 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.3%, Rev. 2.5%) 

US

President Trump is said to believe he has the authority to replace Fed Chair Powell but will not remove him for now. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%, while it maintained forward guidance of keeping rates at extremely low levels at least through to Spring 2020. Furthermore, the BoJ said its decision to maintain QQE with YCC was made by 7-2 votes with Harada and Kataoka the dissenters, and stated the economy is likely expanding moderately as a trend which is likely to continue although output and exports are impacted by overseas slowdown. (Newswires)

RBA Governor Lowe said the possibility of lower rates remain on the table and that it is not unrealistic to expect a further reduction in the Cash Rate. Governor Lowe also commented that recent data suggests we are not making any inroads into the economy's spare capacity and it is unrealistic to think one 25bps cut can alter the growth path, while he also suggested that it is important to recognize monetary policy is not the only option and that he is very hopeful we will not need to cut as far as some central banks in Europe. (Newswires)

Norges Bank unanimously delivered on the promised 25bps June hike, with the Key Rate now at 1.25%, as expected.” Governor Olsen highlighted that the “assessment of the outlook and balance of risks suggests that the policy rate will most likely be increased further in the course of 2019”, with policy forecasts signalling faster rate rises in the coming years. In-fitting with some of the calls, the rate path was left unchanged from the March release. The NB did however acknowledge that a deepening in trade tensions and softer oil prices could weigh on the domestic economy. All-in-all a hawkish hike, which was reflected by the markets as NOK strengthened.

ECB's de Guindos (Neutral) says the Bank is ready to act if the deterioration continues. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian Revolutionary Guard shot down a US drone according to reports citing the state news agency, although the US military later stated that no US aircraft had operated in Iranian airspace. (Associated Press/Newswires) Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corp Top Commander Salami says the the downing of the US drone sent a clear message to Washington, according to State TV. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Retail Sales MM (May) -0.5% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Rev. -0.1%) (Newswires)

China-EU investment access talks went better than expected, according to diplomatic sources, The talks also went “deeper than normal” and the parties agreed to hold further meetings each month from July to speed up the process, sources stated. (SCMP)

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +0.8%] as the region carries the FOMC-spark gains from Wall Street and Asia overnight. UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.5%) marginally lags its peers as the index is pressured by a firmer Sterling ahead of the BoE Monetary Policy Meeting. Sectors are also broadly in green, albeit financial names lag amid the post-FOMC yield decline. In terms of individual movers, Dixons Carphone (-13%) sunk to the bottom of the Stoxx 600 after the Co. cut guidance. Meanwhile, Fresenius Medical Care (+2.1%) is supported by a positive Barclays broker move. Finally, more bad news for Deutsche Bank (-1.1%) after NYT reported of a criminal probe over alleged money laundering.

FX

DXY - The Dollar is down across the board as the FOMC matched market expectations by shifting further towards a rate cut, while Fed chair Powell delivered an extra dovish snippet in the press conference by revealing that even those not plotting an ease are more prone towards loosening monetary policy if needed. The has now index lost grip of the 97.000 handle and extended losses towards 96.500, with chart support just below (ie the 96.459 post-NFP low) under threat ahead of weekly claims, Philly Fed and the LEI.

NOK/NZD/CHF - The G10 outperformers, with the Norwegian Crown benefiting from a hawkish Norges Bank hike on top of the aforementioned Greenback weakness, and also further divergence vs the ECB as the revised rate path pencils in 2 more 25 bp tightening moves (next in September 2019 and 3rd before Summer next year). Usd/Nok and Eur/Nok down to circa 8.5500 and 9.6630 respectively in response. Meanwhile, the Kiwi and Franc drew additional impetus from data in the form of NZ Q1 y/y GDP and Swiss trade, as Nzd/Usd rebounds firmly towards 0.6600 and Usd/Chf retreats sharply through 0.9900, with 0.9850 in sight.

EUR/AUD/CAD/GBP - The next best majors in terms of gains relative to the Buck, as the single currency tests 1.1300 and unwinds more post-Draghi declines, while the Aussie pivots 0.6900 even though RBA Governor Lowe underscores room for further OCR cuts and the CBA believes back-to-back easing is in the offing with another ¼ point reduction in July. Elsewhere, the Loonie has built on Wednesday’s strong headline Canadian CPI platform to probe 1.3200 offers and psychological resistance and the Pound has reclaimed 1.2700+ status ahead of the BoE amidst market expectations or perceptions that the outturn might be hawkish on balance – see the headline feed or Research Suite for a more detailed preview. Note, not much reaction in Cable to UK retail sales that were weak and came with back data downgrades as the ONS flagged bad weather impacting clothes and footwear in mitigation.

EM - Broad rallies or rebounds at the Dollar’s expense, but the Lira also gleaning impetus to breach 5.7500 via an improvement in Turkish consumer sentiment, while the Rand is testing 14.2000 in anticipation of SA President Ramaphosa’s SOTU address and the Ruble is getting an oil-related boost and rallied to 63.2400 at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Notwithstanding hefty block trades in US Treasury futures and options that appeared to be bullish given transaction and strike levels vs live prices prevailing at the time, core debt futures have cooled off appreciably. Indeed, Bunds are just off 172.41 Eurex lows compared to 172.70 at best, as Gilts hover a few ticks above their new 130.38 Liffe base and the 10 year T-note sits roughly midway between 128-08-127-26 overnight session parameters, with the corresponding yield displaying a distinct reluctance or stickiness around the 2% marker. Ahead, the BoE, some decent US releases and Treasury issuance details for next weak that could al be weighing on sentiment alongside a degree of post-Fed reappraisal after the initially dovish take.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures extended on gains in early European trade as the upside seen amid the dovish FOMC was exacerbated by reports that Iran shot down a US spy drone over the Strait of Hormuz, as tensions in the region escalates. WTI futures rose to levels just shy of USD 56.00/bbl whilst its Brent counterpart ran out of steam ahead of USD 64/bbl. Both benchmarks have since come off highs but hold onto a bulk of its gains, amid light news flow in the complex. Elsewhere, gold remains closer to the 1400/oz after having experienced a post-FOMC flash spike, with some attributing the move to a breakout from a five year range. Meanwhile, copper is back above the USD 2.70/lb amid a weaker Dollar and upbeat risk sentiment around the market. Finally, Dalian iron ore hit fresh record highs after Rio Tinto yesterday lowered its Pilbara shipment guidance, suggesting that supply could remain tight despite Vale resuming operations at its Brucutu Mine.

subject: Bunds: bulls revived by Fed’s flagging patience
content: The 10 year German benchmark is grinding higher again, partly on the back of the renewed post-FOMC bid in US Treasuries, but also as ECB members continue to contemplate various forms of monetary stimulus and July policy easing expectations rise accordingly. However, bonds are vying for investor attention with stocks and other riskier assets, while Bunds are also conceding ground or contending with outperformance in periphery debt. Hence, the core debt future is hovering just below its 172.88 June 18 contract high within a 172.43-70 Eurex range, albeit firmly above yesterday’s official 172.16 close. Ahead, hefty Spanish and French supply before some key US data and preliminary Eurozone consumer confidence that is forecast to remain at -6.5, but could easily beat or miss given the aforementioned heightened prospects of more Central Bank loosening vs recent weak proxies like the ZEW survey.

20th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive as the region digested the dovish FOMC in which the Fed kept rates unchanged as expected but dropped its ‘patient’ reference and lowered rate projections from end-2020 through to the longer-term. Fed Chair Powell also suggested that many participants see a strong case for rate cuts and that even for the participants that don’t, the case for accommodation was stronger now than previously. As such, ASX 200 (+0.2%) was led higher by gold names after the precious metal surged to its highest since 2013 but with upside in the broader market capped by weakness in other miners including Rio Tinto after it lowered its iron ore production outlook and with Caltex heavily pressured on disappointing guidance due to extraordinary challenges in H1. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also supported in the aftermath of the FOMC although a firmer currency and unsurprising BoJ announcement limited the advances, while Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.5%) outperformed on optimism ahead of the US-China trade talks and as financials surged after continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC.

FTSE 100

EX-DIVS: Compass Group (CPG LN), Land Securities (LAND LN) and United Utilities (UU/ LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 1.83 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

Oil names – WTI crude futures extended above the USD 54.00/bbl level as prices remained supported by the recent bullish EIA inventory report and ongoing geopolitical concerns surrounding Iran, as well as reports of a missile strike which hit a desalination plant in Saudi Arabia. (RANsquawk)

Mining names - Gold outperformed post-FOMC and even experienced a flash spike in which the precious metal surged around USD 18/oz in a matter of seconds before eventually reversing the move which some also attributed to a breakout from a 5-year range, while copper also benefitted from the risk tone and as Dalian iron ore prices continued its streak of fresh record highs. subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 20th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • FOMC stood pat on rates, dot plot showed median forecast is for no change in rates in 2019 although nearly half expected lower rates
  • Fed stated it will closely monitor developments and removed its pledge to be “patient”.
  • BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged as expected
  • Boris Johnson maintained the lead in the third Conservative leadership vote, Rory Stewart eliminated
  • Looking ahead, highlights include BoE and Norges rate decisions, UK retail sales, US weekly jobs, Philly Fed, ECB’s de Guindos, BoE’s Carney, ECB’s Rehn, supply from Spain and France

 

FOMC

- FOMC left rates unchanged between 2.25-2.50% as expected but tweaked the language in its statement to reflect a more dovish stance.

- FOMC downgraded its assessment of economic activity to moderate from solid and noted that uncertainties about the outlook have increased.

- Furthermore, the Fed stated it will closely monitor developments and removed its pledge to be “patient”.

- Fed’s Bullard was the only dissenter on rates and favoured a cut.

- Fed dot plots showed median forecast is for no change in rates in 2019 although nearly half expected lower rates in which one policymaker forecasts one cut, 7 anticipate two rate cuts, 8 see rates to remain steady and one sees a rate hike. The median view for the Fed Fund Rates in end-2020 is at 2.1% (Prev. 2.6%); end-2021 at 2.4% (Prev. 2.6%) and longer run at 2.5% (Prev. 2.8%).

- Fed sees growth slightly stronger in 2020, jobless rate and inflation are seen slightly lower compared to March projections.

- Fed Chair Powell noted at the press conference that many participants see a strong case for rate cuts and that even among the participants who did not see rate cuts, the case for accommodation was stronger now than in the previous meeting. Powell also stated that many participants cited weaker business investment and cross currents as the reason for cuts, while participants also anticipate inflation moving to the target more slowly than expected although he reverted back to the “monitoring” language when explicitly asked about whether the Fed would cut at the upcoming meeting. (Newswires) 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive as the region digested the dovish FOMC. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was led higher by gold names after the precious metal surged to its highest since 2013 but with upside in the broader market capped by weakness in other miners including Rio Tinto after it lowered its iron ore production outlook and with Caltex heavily pressured on disappointing guidance. Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also supported in the aftermath of the FOMC although a firmer currency and unsurprising BoJ announcement limited the advances, while Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.5%) outperformed on optimism ahead of the US-China trade talks and as financials surged after continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they tracked the upside in T-notes amid a decline in global yields with the US 10yr yield below 2.00% for the first time since November 2016 and with the 30yr yield also at similar multi-year lows.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos. PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8805 (Prev. 6.8893)

Early talks suggest G20 members' frustration regarding US-China trade spat and that there is mounting pressure on the world's two largest economies to ease trade tensions. (FT)

US President Trump and Chinese President Xi are expected to meet over dinner on June 29th in Japan. President Trump says he will also be meeting with Russian President Putin at the G20. (Newswires)

USTR Lighthizer said will meet with China VP Liu He this week and again before the Trump-Xi meeting at G20. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li told visiting foreign Co. CEOs that China will maintain commitment to reform and opening up and will also relax restrictions on access to even more sectors. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor questioned on Twitter whether China and the US are set to have new decisive negotiations and stated that he and the people around him are less optimistic than they were when the two leaders met last December, while he believes Trump's call is a result of the fight from the Chinese side and that more battles may be needed for making the US fairer. (Twitter)

BoJ kept monetary policy settings unchanged as expected with NIRP held at -0.1% and 10yr JGB yield target at around 0%, while it maintained forward guidance of keeping rates at extremely low levels at least through to Spring 2020. Furthermore, the BoJ said its decision to maintain QQE with YCC was made by 7-2 votes with Harada and Kataoka the dissenters, and stated the economy is likely expanding moderately as a trend which is likely to continue although output and exports are impacted by overseas slowdown. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Boris Johnson maintained the lead in the third Conservative leadership vote with 143 votes vs. Jeremy Hunt at 54 votes, Michael Gove at 51 votes, Sajid Javid at 38 votes and Rory Stewart eliminated with 27 votes. (Newswires) Reports suggest supporters of Johnson are looking to mount an operation to derail Gove’s leadership hopes. (Telegraph)

Italy’s ruling coalition drafted a bill to reform the BoI's management which will be proposed by the govt and parliament. (Newswires)

FX

DXY weakened and fell below 97.00 in the wake of the FOMC. As such, EUR/USD and GBP/USD extended above 1.1250 and 1.2650 respectively, while USD/JPY slipped below 108.00 to its weakest levels since January due to USD softness and after an unsurprising BoJ announcement. Antipodeans were underpinned by the Fed and with gains in NZD/USD exacerbated by better than expected Q1 GDP, although further advances in AUD/USD was capped by resistance at 0.6900 and dovish comments by RBA Governor Lowe who suggested further rate cuts remain on the table.

RBA Governor Lowe said the possibility of lower rates remain on the table and that it is not unrealistic to expect a further reduction in the Cash Rate. Governor Lowe also commented that recent data suggests we are not making any inroads into the economy's spare capacity and it is unrealistic to think one 25bps cut can alter the growth path, while he also suggested that it is important to recognize monetary policy is not the only option and that he is very hopeful we will not need to cut as far as some central banks in Europe. (Newswires)

New Zealand GDP (Q1) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.6%), Y/Y 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.3%, Rev. 2.5%)

COMMODITIES 

Commodities were higher across the board with advances in the complex fuelled by a weaker greenback and dovish FOMC. This saw WTI crude futures extend above the USD 54.00/bbl level as prices remained supported by the recent bullish EIA inventory report and ongoing geopolitical concerns surrounding Iran, as well as reports of a missile strike which hit a desalination plant in Saudi Arabia. Elsewhere, gold outperformed post-FOMC and even experienced a flash spike in which the precious metal surged around USD 18/oz in a matter of seconds before eventually reversing the move which some also attributed to a breakout from a 5-year range, while copper also benefitted from the risk tone and as Dalian iron ore prices continued its streak of fresh record highs.

 

UAE Energy Minister said the country supports a decision to extend OPEC+ production cuts and that an extension to the cuts is reasonable as the market's position requires it. (Al Bayan)

GEOPOLITICS

 

US White House Press Secretary Sanders said President Trump has been briefed on details of a missile strike in Saudi Arabia, which unverified reports noted hit a desalination plant. (Newswires)

Iranian Revolutionary Guard shot down a US drone according to reports citing the state news agency, although the US military later stated that no US aircraft had operated in Iranian airspace. (Associated Press/Newswires)

US

The Treasury curve bull-steepened after a dovish FOMC meeting, where the Fed held rates though tweaked its guidance in a dovish manner and reiterated a willingness to act if the situation required. The near-end of the Treasury yield curve saw further lows (2s see a 1.5yr low, 3s nearly a 20-month low), though the 10-year note again is clinging to a 2-handle at settlement, though it is only a couple of basis points from going under 2%. At settlement, 2s30s was nearly 8bps wider. In terms of pricing for Fed cuts, 29.5bps of cuts has been priced for July (vs 24.9bps prior to today's rate decision); by end 2019, 71.5bps of cuts are priced (vs 60.5bps before the rate decision). US T-note futures (U9) settled 11+ ticks higher at 127-27+.

President Trump is said to believe he has the authority to replace Fed Chair Powell but will not remove him for now. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump intends to keep the government open and that the White House will propose a one-year continuing resolution as well debt limit hike if no deal is made. (CNBC)

Potential Fed nominee Shelton said she would like to see lower rates as fast as possible. (Washington Post)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gain as the region digests the dovish Fed
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly positive as the region digests the dovish FOMC in which the Fed kept rates unchanged as expected but dropped its ‘patient’ reference and lowered rate projections from end-2020 through to the longer-term. Fed Chair Powell also suggested that many participants see a strong case for rate cuts and that even for the participants that don’t, the case for accommodation was stronger now than previously. As such, ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by gold names after the precious metal surged to its highest since 2013 but with upside in the broader market capped by weakness in other miners including Rio Tinto after it lowered its iron ore production forecasts and with Caltex heavily pressured on disappointing guidance due to extraordinary challenges in H1. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was also supported in the aftermath of the FOMC although a firmer currency and looming BoJ announcement limited the advances, while Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.3%) conformed to the upbeat tone following another liquidity effort by the PBoC and optimism ahead of the US-China trade talks at the G20.

In FX markets, the DXY weakened and fell below the 97.00 level in the wake of the FOMC which saw markets price in 29.5bps of cuts for July (Prev. 24.9bps) and 71.5bps of cuts priced by end-2019 (Prev. 60.5bps), despite Fed Chair Powell stopping short of declaring a cut for July and instead reverted back to the “monitoring” language when asked about a cut for next month. This benefitted the greenback’s major counterparts across the board with EUR/USD and GBP/USD extending above 1.1250 and 1.2650 respectively, while USD/JPY slipped below 108.00 to its weakest levels since January. Elsewhere, antipodeans were also underpinned by the Fed and with gains in NZD/USD exacerbated by better than expected Q1 GDP, although AUD/USD began to consolidate after hitting resistance at the 0.6900 handle and on cross-related flows in which AUD/NZD slipped below 1.0500.

Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they tracked the upside in T-notes amid a decline in yields with the US 10yr yield below 2.00% which is its lowest level since November 2016 and with the 30yr yield also at similar multi-year lows. Gold was another notable mover overnight and briefly spiked by around 2.5% higher on the session to levels last seen in 2013 due to the softer greenback and which some attributed to stops being triggered after a breakout of a 5-year range.
